Topic.Title: Techstrategy, what are your other positions?

Message.Msg: Let me simplify for you. I would take either in a paired trade. My original recommendation was GOOG and I stand behind that. I am about to start slowly adding to my Google position via LT OOM calls. If it drops, so be it. INTC is simply one of if not the best long term investments I see right now. I know a fair amount about technology having worked with hundreds of nanotech companies across the past decade. INTC is one helluva company. We don't value manufacturing in the US anymore (ironically, the operational efficiency/six sigma/black belt made GE one of the most valuable companies in the world...), but INTC is the BEST manufacturing company in the world and the global trade and currency dynamics will enhance its competitiveness long term.

Topic.Title: Techstrategy, what are your other positions?

Message.Msg: Sybs: I play a different game. INTC will probably fall a little more. I'm okay with that. Feeling the pain actually helps me to gauge where we are in the behavioral investing squeeze play, which is what the markets are really about right now. If you do not have a position, you don't really have a sense of how insanely overextended it is and thus how far it will eventually move in the other direction.

Topic.Title: countijng my money for tomorrow and earning right now!

Message.Msg: Hi Buter, You are correct. My analysis on the board is often for my own entertainent. I have made a long play on AMZN for reasons that are rather simple, but maybe not completely obvious to all investors. The first is that AMZN enacted a 15% fee on all their direct vendor at the beginning of the year for "marketing", but it goes to their own bottom line of course. They have also become a much savvier retailer on chargebacks and other fees. These add to a retailer's bottom line hugely. The second is my own interactions with multiple brands with sales on AMZN that have been growing nearly exponentially this year, nevermind the chatter in my own industry that AMZN is a force. I also figure that if Best Buy, Walmart, and Target are all price matching/kicking out the Kindle--that's a pretty fair assumption that AMZN is making an impact on their bottom line. This gives me reason to believe that Q3 was big and Q4 should also look really good...since we're 15% off the highs, I like this gamble. Maybe it works, maybe not.

Topic.Title: Sorry to break this to you, shorts . . . but . . .

Message.Msg: There are no institutional investors buying Amazon. The longs have unloaded as much as possible via the upper deck to traders... Amazon held its ground today purely because the market was down so big (money comes in to squeeze and longs let it happen so that Amazon is higher to sell much bigger volume into any market strength to follow). What is Amazon's FCF yield again?
